input_text.content:
The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept. The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe tread analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

metadata.title: White House Report Concludes That Bite-Mark Analysis Is Junk Science
metadata.author: Jordan Smith

input_text.context_portion:
The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept. The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe t
input_text.completion_portion: read analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

results.output_text:
read and tire tread analysis, and hair and fiber analysis. The council found that many of these practices are not rooted in scientific methodology and lack the necessary validation to be considered reliable evidence. They highlight that these methods are often based on subjective interpretation, which can lead to errors and potentially wrongful convictions.

The council has recommended that these methods should not be used as primary evidence in criminal cases until they are properly validated. They also urged for the creation of national standards and guidelines for forensic science, in order to increase the reliability and validity of these practices.

This report comes at a crucial time, when the reliability of forensic evidence has been increasingly questioned. Many cases have been overturned due to faulty forensic evidence, leading to calls for reform in the field. The council's findings could potentially lead to significant changes in the way forensic evidence is used in the courtroom. 

The President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology is comprised of leading scientists and engineers who provide advice to the President on matters related to science and technology. Their examination of these common forensic practices could have a profound effect on the justice system, changing how evidence is collected, analyzed, and presented in court. 

It remains to be seen how the recommendations in this report will be implemented, and what impact they will have on future criminal investigations and trials. However, it is clear that there is a pressing need for reform in the field of forensic science.

input_text.content:
The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept. The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe tread analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

metadata.title: White House Report Concludes That Bite-Mark Analysis Is Junk Science
metadata.author: Jordan Smith

input_text.context_portion:
The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology has concluded that forensic bite-mark evidence is not scientifically valid and is unlikely ever to be validated, according to a draft report obtained by The Intercept. The report, titled “Forensic Science in Criminal Courts: Ensuring Scientific Validity of Feature-Comparison Methods,” is marked as a “predecisional” draft created August 26 that is not to be quoted or distributed, though the title page suggests the report will be made public sometime this month.
The report reviews a handful of common forensic practices, so called feature-comparison disciplines, or pattern-matching practices — bite-mark analysis, fingerprint and firearm analysis, shoe t
input_text.completion_portion: read analysis, and DNA mixture analysis — each of which involves an “expert” looking at a piece of evidence and eyeballing whether it matches a particular image, person, or object.

results.output_text:
read and tire tread analysis, among others. The advisors warn that these techniques do not meet the stringent requirements of scientific validity and reliability, and can lead to erroneous and misleading conclusions in a court of law.

The Council highlights that the scientific community does not generally accept bite-mark analysis due to its inherent subjectivity, lack of accurate methods to measure bite marks, and the inability to definitively link a bite mark to a specific individual. It argues that the lack of rigorous scientific research and protocols leaves the method open to bias and error.

Furthermore, the report points out that the same issues apply to other forensic techniques such as fingerprint, shoe and tire tread analysis. There is a lack of standardization and validation across these fields, and the interpretation of results can often be subjective.

The Council recommends that these practices should be subjected to rigorous, systematic scrutiny before they can be accepted as scientifically valid and reliable evidence in court. It specifically calls for more research, improved standards and protocols, and increased transparency in forensic science.

The draft report's conclusions echo the findings of a 2009 report by the National Academy of Sciences, which found that many forensic practices lack the necessary scientific underpinning to be considered reliable.

The President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology is an advisory group of the nation’s leading scientists and engineers who directly advise the President and the Executive Office of the President. The Council provides advice on a wide range of topics, including forensic science, with the aim of ensuring that the policies of the U.S. government are grounded in sound science.

input_text.content:
Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton held rallies at nearly the same time on Tuesday, with Trump doing an event in Virginia and Clinton holding one in Florida.
Trump, in a national-security focused Q&A with former Defense Intelligence Agency chief Michael Flynn, described the Iran-Iraq war in flippant terms, saying that the two countries would “fight fight fight.

metadata.title: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Hold Dueling Rallies — But Trump Gets Most of the TV Coverage
metadata.author: Zaid Jilani

input_text.context_portion:
Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton held rallies at nearly the same time on Tuesday, with Trump doing an event in Virginia and Clinton holding one in Florida.
Trump, in a national-security focused Q&A with former Defense Intelligence Agency chief Michael Flynn, described the Iran-Iraq war i
input_text.completion_portion: n flippant terms, saying that the two countries would “fight fight fight.

results.output_text:
n the 1980s as a "disastrous conflict" that destabilized the Middle East and led to the current crisis. He criticized the Obama administration, which Clinton was part of, for not taking stronger action to prevent Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons. 

On the other hand, Clinton, in a rally held in Miami, focused on domestic issues such as healthcare, immigration, and gun control. She criticized Trump’s approach to foreign policy, calling it "reckless" and "uninformed". She also highlighted her experience as Secretary of State, assuring her supporters that she had the necessary skills and knowledge to handle international affairs. 

Both candidates used their rallies to rally their supporters and criticize their opponent as the November election approaches.

input_text.content:
Ten Indian trade unions staged one of the largest strikes in human history on Friday, with tens of millions of public sector workers participating in a shutdown of parts of the Indian economy to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s economic plans.
But if you’re an American relying on cable news, it would be hard to know it ever happened.

metadata.title: Indians Staged One of the Largest Strikes in History, But No One on U.S. Cable News Covered It
metadata.author: Zaid Jilani

input_text.context_portion:
Ten Indian trade unions staged one of the largest strikes in human history on Friday, with tens of millions of public sector workers participating in a shutdown of parts of the Indian economy to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s economic plans.
But if you’re an Ameri
input_text.completion_portion: can relying on cable news, it would be hard to know it ever happened.

results.output_text: can, you may not have heard about it. Mainstream U.S. media outlets largely ignored the protest, focusing instead on domestic issues or other international events. The strike, organized by some of India's most powerful trade unions, was held in opposition to proposed labor reforms and economic policies put forth by Prime Minister Modi's government, which the unions claim favor big business and neglect the rights and needs of workers. These include changes to labor laws, privatization of public sector work and increases in foreign investment. Workers from various sectors such as banking, mining, construction and transportation took part in the strike, disrupting services and leading to significant economic impact. Despite the scale of the protest, it received little attention or coverage in the U.S. media.

input_text.content:
Ten Indian trade unions staged one of the largest strikes in human history on Friday, with tens of millions of public sector workers participating in a shutdown of parts of the Indian economy to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s economic plans.
But if you’re an American relying on cable news, it would be hard to know it ever happened.

metadata.title: Indians Staged One of the Largest Strikes in History, But No One on U.S. Cable News Covered It
metadata.author: Zaid Jilani

input_text.context_portion:
Ten Indian trade unions staged one of the largest strikes in human history on Friday, with tens of millions of public sector workers participating in a shutdown of parts of the Indian economy to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s economic plans.
But if you’re an Ameri
input_text.completion_portion: can relying on cable news, it would be hard to know it ever happened.

results.output_text:
can, this news might have flown under your radar. The mainstream media in the U.S. largely overlooked the event, focusing instead on domestic issues. 

The strikers, who included bank employees, factory workers, miners, construction workers, and others, were protesting against what they see as the Modi government's pro-business, anti-worker reforms. These include proposed changes to labor laws, privatization of public sector enterprises, and the introduction of a new national sales tax.

The Indian government argues these reforms are necessary to modernize the country's economy and attract foreign investment. However, the unions contend they will erode workers' rights and benefits, leading to job insecurity and worsening working conditions. 

The strike's impact was most visible in the states of Kerala, Karnataka, and West Bengal, where public transport was disrupted, and many schools and businesses were forced to close. However, the Indian government downplayed the strike's effects, claiming that it had minimal impact on the economy.

This massive protest underscores the profound economic and social tensions in India, a country with one of the world's fastest-growing economies but also high levels of poverty and inequality. As Modi's government continues to push for economic liberalization, opposition from labor unions and other social groups is likely to intensify. 

For Americans, this strike serves as a reminder of the global nature of labor struggles and the importance of staying informed about events beyond our borders. Despite the lack of coverage in the U.S. media, the Indian strike carries significant implications for global labor rights and economic justice.

input_text.content: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations. Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt, most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

metadata.title: The Unrelenting Pundit-Led Effort to Delegitimize All Negative Reporting About Hillary Clinton
metadata.author: Glenn Greenwald

input_text.context_portion: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations. Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt,
input_text.completion_portion: most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

results.output_text:
even when there's no evidence to support such allegations."

Krugman lamented that the constant scrutiny and negative coverage of Clinton has created a false equivalence between her and her political opponents, thereby painting an unfair and distorted image of her. He asserted that the media's obsession with Clinton's supposed scandals, from her private email server to the Clinton Foundation, has overshadowed her policy proposals and political achievements.

Krugman argued that while Clinton is not perfect, she is unquestionably qualified to be president. He underlined that the media's fixation on Clinton's perceived flaws has created a misleading narrative that she is a dishonest and untrustworthy candidate. This notion, he claimed, is not rooted in facts but rather in media bias and partisan politics.

In his column, Krugman also criticized the media's coverage of Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee. He suggested that the media has been too lenient on Trump, failing to hold him accountable for his false statements and controversial actions.

Krugman concluded by urging journalists to be more objective in their coverage of the presidential election. He stressed the importance of accurate reporting, arguing that the media has a responsibility to inform the public, not to shape public opinion based on unfounded accusations and false equivalencies.

metadata.title: The Unrelenting Pundit-Led Effort to Delegitimize All Negative Reporting About Hillary Clinton
metadata.author: Glenn Greenwald

input_text.context_portion: In his New York Times column yesterday, Paul Krugman did something that he made clear he regarded as quite brave: He defended the Democratic Party presidential nominee and likely next U.S. president from journalistic investigations. Complaining about media bias, Krugman claimed that journalists are driven by “the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt,
input_text.completion_portion: most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation.

results.output_text:
even when there is no concrete evidence to support such an assertion." He further argued that this bias has led to an overblown focus on Clinton's alleged misdeeds, while ignoring or downplaying equally or more serious concerns about her opponent. 

Krugman's column comes at a time when Clinton's candidacy has been dogged by controversies, most notably over her use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State. However, the economist-turned-columnist argued that the media's obsession with Clinton's emails and other scandals is disproportionate and unfair. 

He also criticized the tendency of some in the media to create a false equivalence between Clinton and her opponent, arguing that this only serves to normalize the latter's behavior and deflect attention away from his own issues. 

According to Krugman, the media's pursuit of a 'balanced' narrative has resulted in a skewed portrayal of Clinton, damaging her public image and potentially influencing the outcome of the election.

While acknowledging that Clinton is not without flaws, Krugman insisted that the constant vilification of her character is unwarranted, given the lack of substantial proof of any wrongdoing. He concluded by urging journalists to exercise more discernment and fairness in their coverage of the presidential race.

input_text.content:
I’m going to have a story published later today about a new document, but until then, this new interview with (and profile of) Director of National Intelligence James Clapper by the Daily Beast‘s Eli Lake is worth spending a few moments examining. Last week, Lake published one excerpt of his interview where Clapper admitted that the U.S. Government should have told the American people that the NSA was collecting their communications records: as pure a vindication of Edward Snowden’s choice as it gets, for obvious reasons. But there are several new, noteworthy revelations from this morning’s article:
Thanks to rogue contractor Edward Snowden, the machinations of the shadow bureaucracy Clapper heads have for the last eight months been exposed one news story at a time. Clapper is often the guy who has to call newspaper editors to tell them not to print stories that they usually publish anyway.
This process of pre-publication notice to the government of NSA stories has been wildly misreported in some places.

metadata.title: Inside the Mind of James Clapper
metadata.author: Glenn Greenwald

input_text.context_portion:
I’m going to have a story published later today about a new document, but until then, this new interview with (and profile of) Director of National Intelligence James Clapper by the Daily Beast‘s Eli Lake is worth spending a few moments examining. Last week, Lake published one excerpt of his interview where Clapper admitted that the U.S. Government should have told the American people that the NSA was collecting their communications records: as pure a vindication of Edward Snowden’s choice as it gets, for obvious reasons. But there are several new, noteworthy revelations from this morning’s article:
Thanks to rogue contractor Edward Snowden, the machinations of the shadow bureaucracy Clapper heads have for the last eight months been exposed one news story at a time. Clapper is often the guy who has to ca
input_text.completion_portion:
ll newspaper editors to tell them not to print stories that they usually publish anyway.
This process of pre-publication notice to the government of NSA stories has been wildly misreported in some places.

results.output_text:
lm the storm, explain to Congress, and defend the practices of the intelligence community. In the interview, Clapper talked about the balance that needs to be struck between security and privacy. He stated that while the government has a responsibility to protect its citizens, it also has a responsibility not to infringe on their privacy.

Perhaps most revealing was Clapper's admission that the intelligence community had been too secretive in the past. He stated that they needed to be more transparent in their operations, though he did not specify how this transparency would be achieved. This reflects a significant change in Clapper's previous stance, where he had staunchly defended the need for secrecy in intelligence operations.

Furthermore, Clapper provided insight into how the intelligence community operates and the challenges it faces. He discussed how intelligence is gathered, how it is analyzed, and how it is used to inform policy decisions. He also touched on the difficulties of predicting events, given the vast amount of information that is collected and the complexities of global politics.

Most notably, Clapper acknowledged the need for reforms in the way the intelligence community operates. He mentioned the need for better oversight and stricter controls on surveillance operations, echoing the sentiments of many critics who have called for changes in the wake of the Snowden revelations. This suggests that Clapper is open to a more balanced approach to intelligence gathering, one that respects the rights of individuals while still protecting national security. 

In conclusion, this interview provides a rare glimpse into the mind of one of the most powerful figures in the U.S. intelligence community, and offers some hope that changes may be on the horizon.
